title: Rude TSA agent? Review them on Yelp
text:
CNN Leadership
Rude TSA agent? Review them on Yelp Updated 0129 GMT (0829 HKT) August 21, 2015 8 photos: Peer pressure Peer pressure – Thanks to apps such as Uber and AirBnb, a bad review now cuts both ways. The peer review is increasingly a feature of everything from holidays and restaurants to cab rides and flat shares. Hide Caption 1 of 8 8 photos: Peer pressure Peer pressure – Online customer reviews - in particular industry giants like Tripadvisor - are now big business and the main factor in influencing consumer choices. Hide Caption 2 of 8 8 photos: Peer pressure Peer pressure – In many cases, online reviews are beginning to make the old star rating for hotels obsolete. Analysts say that while there are still different expectations for different price categories, it's easier to look at reviews and see what people are saying and to make booking decision based on that. Hide Caption 3 of 8 8 photos: Peer pressure Peer pressure – Everything from wine to dog sitters and even parking spots are being peer reviewed online. Analysts say that these reviews are changing the marketing landscape. Hide Caption 4 of 8 8 photos: Peer pressure Peer pressure – The internet has made it even easier for word to spread quickly about the quality of all kinds of services. Sites such as Yelp have been credited with revolutionizing the restaurant review business. Hide Caption Uber has been the subject of several protests in various cities. Hide Caption Berlin taxi drivers protest over Uber. Hide Caption 7 of 8 8 photos: Peer pressure Each Uber user has a rating, but it is only visible to drivers who are in range for a pick up. Hide Caption Story highlights Travelers will be able to post reviews of the TSA on the agency's Yelp page The idea is to make government more accountable, but it also gives people a place to vent (CNN) If a TSA agent treats you rudely in an airport security line, you don't have to just seethe silently. You can fire back -- on Yelp. That's right: No longer must you limit your scathing, one-star reviews to that overpriced Italian restaurant with the lousy osso buco. Yelp has announced an agreement with the federal government to allow the TSA and other federal agencies to claim Yelp pages and respond to reviews. It's not a drastic change. Travelers have been posting comments -- well, mostly complaints -- about the Transportation Security Administration on an assortment of Yelp pages for years. But this would gather them in one official place, monitored by TSA staffers who would incorporate feedback into service improvements. The idea is to make government more accountable to its citizens . In practice, it mostly gives its angriest citizens a place to vent. The TSA now has official pages on Yelp, where travelers can leave reviews. The vast majority of customer reviews on Yelp's unofficial TSA pages are of the one- or two-star variety, filled with such choice phrases as "a joke," "total bozos" and "a crappy knockoff of the Gestapo." While a few travelers post positive feedback, others gripe about unfriendly TSA agents and invasive pat-downs. GOP presidential candidate Carly Fiorina even took advantage of the announcement this week to post a one-star review of the TSA , calling it an example of an inept federal bureaucracy that she will fix if elected. Given that most Americans' exposure to the TSA is in the airport security line -- a stressful place for many travelers -- the agency may not be eager for Yelp feedback. Asked Thursday about the new Yelp deal, a TSA spokesman sounded less than enthusiastic. "We're still learning more about it," David Castelveter said, adding that the TSA already fields comments on Twitter , where it has almost 60,000 followers between its 12 accounts. "We believe that there are more benefits to a real-time, two-way exchange between the TSA and travelers on Twitter," he said. 15 photos: A cornucopia of TSA-seized items 15 photos: A cornucopia of TSA-seized items The U.S. Transportation Security Administration seized a record 2,212 firearms from carry-on luggage in 2014. This semiautomatic handgun was found June 15 in a carry-on bag at a security checkpoint at Detroit Metropolitan Airport. Hide Caption 1 of 15 15 photos: A cornucopia of TSA-seized items Guns are far from the only weapons and prohibited items confiscated at checkpoints. On November 18, a wide range of objects, including fake grenades and ammunition, were confiscated and photographed at New York's John F. Kennedy International Airport. Click through the rest of the photos to see what else was seized that day. Hide Caption 15 photos: A cornucopia of TSA-seized items A piece of weaponry-related artwork was seized November 18 at JFK. Hide Caption 15 photos: A cornucopia of TSA-seized items Hammers and other tools were also seized. Hide Caption 15 photos: A cornucopia of TSA-seized items So was a meat cleaver ...
